title: Is Ethereum Really in Trouble? Foundation Exec Breaks Silence!

cleanText: The Ethereum community is much stronger. It's just temporarily demotivated. I still feel very, very much that pain that all the users feel. Absolutely no chance that DeFi will not dominate all the global markets. It will be there. It will happen on Ethereum. Hide from ECC here in K. We are celebrating 10 years of Ethereum and we are exploring the future of Ethereum. It's a fantastic uh opportunity to chat to Tomasz Stanczak who's the co-executive director of the Ethereum Foundation. A new role for you. Let's start off there, Tomas. Um, what's it been like stepping into this role, uh, being sort of a northstar for the Ethereum ecosystem, um, over the last six months? So the last six months, obviously the beginning of the year, a bit bumpy with a lot of criticism, but I think the changes were already happening. It's just, uh, sometimes you have like social media criticizing something that's that's already moving in the right direction. So rejoining in March was, um, just continuation of the process that the board started, uh, many months ago, I think September last year. Obviously, there's been a lot of criticism directed at the at the foundation, which is, you know, I mean, we could talk at length about that. But at what stage was there sort of a realization that these new next-generation, uh, blockchains have come around and Ethereum needs to do something to either catch up or, uh, accelerate the speed of change to to match what the rest of the industry is doing? I wouldn't like to immediately accept there's a realization that there is a new generation and something suddenly you have to accelerate. Looking at the US markets where Solana is focusing on the, uh, on the solutions for for financial trading there. Look at Vitalik's comments at the time when, uh, when Solana was struggling. He was saying that there is there is good solid development there. Uh, so, so people knew that something good might be coming, and just the question was maybe how, how Ethereum will be perceived and how much of pressure it will be for Ethereum to go in that direction and and then realization that it's a bit harder to operate and show and clarify in the in a message in the communication. Um, that's, uh, the combination of Ethereum values. Yeah, the quality of technology that there are some sacrifices that cannot be made, and those are, uh, like those are components, properties of Ethereum that keeps going for for years after years after years, uh, without stopping and with with attracting the the institutions that are thinking very long term, that they can deploy and they can either control the L2 or or they'll be able to just simply always expect the L1 to be independent, neutral, globally neutral. When you look at the landscape between the Ethereum L1 and L2s, obviously there was a massive shift to bring scale and throughput through L2s. I asked Joe Lubin last year like at what stage do things become a bit too disjointed and fractured and how do you bring things back? Has that been a big focus for the Ethereum Foundation and and the leadership in general? Um, yeah, I think the big focus now is on the interoperability, on the tooling, and on the standards, uh, and accelerating that idea that all the chains around Ethereum should feel very much like a single ecosystem, and it should be very natural for the users to transfer between them to use all the applications that, uh, just just flow through different chains if if they need to. Um, we still really, really appreciate the the effort on the BD, on marketing, on onboarding users from all the different L2s, and they should have their branding, they should have their ecosystems, they should have their niches, uh, they should have their explorations, innovations, and so on, and really Ethereum benefits from that so much, and it will continue that feeling of the entire ecosystem being disjointed. Uh, maybe, you know, like some, some sometimes I think that it starts with people, how they, how they take it, whether they can internalize that that multiple brands still, uh, orbit around Ethereum as a chain that that is really underpinning, uh, and I think it's it's more with how people feel than how technology is constructed. Uh, sure, there are there are clear challenges on, uh, on presenting how, how the fee structure, data availability, how all of this works together, how the interoperability mechanisms work. I just that few years ago it was really hard to predict how all the L2s will be evolving. Uh, and now we see we have much more clarity. I felt very like that UX interoperability was the really the biggest challenge of them all, and now I start feeling better about it. I mean, I remember, uh, interacting with like MetaMask back in the day. I remember trying Uniswap when it first came out, and like it was a clunky experience. So that's why I asked these questions, you know, because it still is. Yeah. So I, I've been playing with various applications and and bridging between chains in the in the last week. So the hope is coming more from understanding all the, uh, all the demos that are there, more like on the testnet side, and with the teams that are building something that show the alpha solutions, uh, but not from production environments, like when I when I go there, and I still feel very, very much that pain that's all the users feel. When you get, uh, feedback from the wider Ethereum community, whether it's validators on the L1 or operators on the L2, what's the biggest pain point right now, and where do people want to see things go? Because my question to Joe Lubin was like, if I'm going to stake 32 ETH and earn a certain return at running a validator versus locking up a load of value on an L2, would it not just be worth my while to do that? And then what's the incentive in the long term for people to continue running validators and keep things sort of centered on the L1? Home stakers are thinking about, do I really align with the values of Ethereum? Do I stake because of that? I don't think in most of the cases when you when you talk to home stakers, they don't do that for, uh, for the yield, right? So it's, it's the large institutions like capital allocators that are doing that for the yield, and they provide security to the network, and then they probably look at the network and think, um, they think from different perspectives of like, what, what are the risks, uh, how stable the the ecosystem is, and, uh, yeah, so risk, all all of the potential risks related to their staking, and and then they choose Ethereum usually for that reason, that it's simply less risky because of all the security efforts, because of all the design of the network, the decentralization. So they think there is less governance risk, there is, uh, less risk of slashing, there's less risk of the, uh, large security events or hacks, uh, so that's their decision. So would say majority of like concerns are, are we going still in the same direction? And and we keep responding saying, yes, yes, yes, we are accelerating, but we want to have both, like both eat cake and have cake. I think that's what the top teams are doing. Um, when you look at the the landscape of the other Layer 1 blockchains, is there a lot of conversation internally about what Solana is doing, what Sui is doing, what Aptos is doing? What's what's good about those user experiences? Do you do sort of like, I mean, we work in a media company, we do competitor analysis. Do you guys do competitor analysis? Um, yes, I'm trying to do more and more of it, like encourage conversations also like the open conversation, invitation of the invitations to the people that are leading other protocols, uh, to talk to our strategy teams, to share, to exchange ideas from the business development side to grow partnerships, uh, convincing everyone in the ecosystem to be very well aware of what is being built. That's a bit more effort now, I think, just sending people hints, look at this, it looks, it looks interesting. How, how other building communities do you think like Solana and some of the other L1s have done better just at community building perhaps in the last two or three years? Uh, so yeah, we've heard a lot about the the super team, but then we also, uh, thought about how, how all the Ethereum events are working, and then on one side, you see that there is a momentum there of bringing new builders, uh, but also we go to lots of communities, they say, you know, we are experts on this, and the Ethereum community is much stronger. It's just temporarily demotivated because of probably that worries from the beginning of the year where they thought, so where we are going now. When you reinvigorate those communities, then suddenly you realize how much of a sleeping giant it is. This year, Vitalik has kind of openly said over the years like, I don't want to be the main character here. I wanted to take a step back. Uh, he came back into the fold to give some fresh direction and shake things up at the Ethereum Foundation. How important was that? And do you still see him playing a pivotal role in the next five years? Uh, yeah, I think it's always very active. It will be always very hard for him to, uh, to not be active in Ethereum and thinking about Ethereum as a product, research area, as a set of values. And you see that that's, uh, he, I think his way of guiding others was just like whenever he he realizes people go in the wrong direction, he'll start being very, very loud about the topic. Uh, so I think this is also the way of communicating between us, like like him and the board and me and the executive, instead of me hearing like, do this to that, I just simply listen to to what he talks about on stage, as everyone else. Uh, and that tells me like, all right, yeah, sure, this is the guidance of the Ethereum values, this is a reminder, uh, you, you know, as an executive, it's very easy to to drift away and start building your own vision, and, um, and I think it's very important to be humble and and think this this is not your role, really, uh, the the people, the ecosystem, community wants go in that direction, and you just want to make it very efficient. I had a fascinating conversation with Sundeep from Polygon, uh, about six months ago, and we were talking about ZK proofs and potentially starting to settle on Bitcoin as opposed to Ethereum, because if you, you can argue the the merits for a more secure, decentralized blockchain between Bitcoin and Ethereum. And he kind of said, you know, if it does get to that point, we could just settle on Bitcoin and do it that way. Is that something that's ever been spoken about internally? Many participants of the ecosystem, they they will look at StarkNet and say, oh, they're at the forefront of, uh, of thinking how to settle in Bitcoin, how to how to do Bitcoin Layer 2, and it's extremely encouraging that it's within the Ethereum ecosystem, and I think this brings great opportunity to to bring a lot of Bitcoin assets to to Ethereum. I think that in the future, seeing Ethereum as a, as a DeFi space for all the BTC or the derivative assets, all the stable coins together, uh, this is what makes it so strong. It'll be really hard to ever oppose the this more like decentralized idea and, uh, and the direction, the governance that comes from the ecosystem. My final question to you, are you optimistic about the the future of Ethereum, and and perhaps more so than you were a year ago? Um, similarly, probably. So I think I try, well, obviously I have to sometimes sound like inspirational, motivational. Not to be overexcited, trying to be realistic. If you think is it DeFi versus TradFi, I would say absolutely no chance that DeFi will not dominate all the global markets. It will be there. It will happen on Ethereum. Um, the SMS might be general about technology and all the challenges of AI, like how quickly we can ensure that the, uh, decentralization solutions, privacy solutions are extremely difficult, but they're very delicate. They're they're hard to design, right? How quickly you can, uh, deliver that before we have the the serious challenges of centralized AI. Tomas, thank you so much for your time. Thank you.
